description:
Earlier this week, the United Nations released its flagship report on the status of women in the global economy. Here're some of its conclusions.

Globally on average women are paid 24% less than men. Women are particularly disadvantaged in Germany where they earn on average 49% less than their male equivalent over their lifetime. It's even worse for Turkish women. They can expect to earn a staggering 75% less. What's more, the report notes, on average women do almost two and a half times more unpaid care and household work than men. And then later in life, just to round it off all neatly, women are more likely to live in poverty, and that's because they're less likely to contribute to a pension than men. All that and it's not as if women haven't been fighting the battle for equality for a while now. Listen to this.

How far are you prepared to go in striking to insist on being skilled labour?

As far as it pays.

How long are you prepared to stay out on strike?

A year.

That was all the way back in 1968. The female workers you heard there were at the Ford plant in Dagenham here in the UK. They won that fight for equal pay. But clearly the UN report shows there's still a long way to go.
